data.title: Weather in Zagreb in July
data.meta_description: Discover the average weather, temperature and general climate of Zagreb in july. Find cheap flights in july and plan your trip to Zagreb on Avionero
data.text:
Going from a maximum of +35°C during the day to a minimum of +12°C during the night, the temperature in July averages around +29°C.

The average maximum temperature goes up 4% by the end of the month, compared with the beginning of the month, from +26°C to +27°C.

Zagreb is typically warm in July.

Maximum temperatures go up compared to the previous month from +25°C to +27°C. The minimum temperature also goes up from +15°C to +16°C.

It’s generally warm, but pack a long-sleeve shirt for evenings.

July is one of the warmest months in Zagreb, here is the comparison with other months:

July weather is still as good as in June. It’s getting warmer as July arrives. The average maximum temperature goes up from +25°C to +27°C during the day. As July arrives, the amount of rainfall goes down. On average, the rainfall volume decreases from 86 mm to 79 mm. It feels drier, as humidity decreases from 70% to 69%. The average wind speed doesn’t change much during July, staying around 1 m/s. The good news is there are likely to be more sunny days in July, from 9 to 12.

August brings much the same weather, it remains good.

The average wind speed is 1 m/s getting up to 3 m/s which is a light breeze; barely moving the tree leaves.

The average wind speed in Zagreb is gradually increasing during July, going from 1 m/s to 1 m/s over the course of the month.

The climate in Zagreb in July has not changed much over the last 43 years.

The average temperature was the lowest in 1980 (+14°C) and the highest in 2022 (+18°C). The driest year was 2011 with only 471 mm of rainfall, and the wettest year was 2019 with 1707 mm.

For this page, we’ve looked at the typical weather in Zagreb, based on historical hourly weather data from January 1, 1979, to December 31, 2022.

For past dates, we show actual recorded data at the location at that time. Forecasts are based on recorded weather during that day of the year, averaged over the total years for which we have records (unless stated otherwise). The daily temperature is the highest recorded temperature in the shadow during that day.
